data.text: Interested in Bikepacking but I'm Out of Shape

So I just bought a bike with plans to get into bikepacking. I've always liked biking, but I haven't done it for about 10 years. So the bike came in, I set it up, then I took it for a test ride. Wow!! I'm so out of shape. I did like 10 minutes only, mostly chill and I'm beat. I feel slightly sick from it. It's so demoralizing.
Just keep pedaling üôå
data.author: Jack Driver

data.text: You‚Äôll get there dude. It doesn‚Äôt matter how fast you‚Äôre going, as long as you‚Äôre moving forward.
data.author: Justin Zabrocki

data.text: yeah, definitely plan to do this daily now to get used to it. Used to be a beast as a kid, now I'm so out of it, it just came as somewhat of a surprise.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: same dude. It‚Äôs crazy how fitness can cal off so dramatically as we age.
data.author: Justin Zabrocki

data.text: Stick with it. Build yourself up gradually and before you know it, you've ridden further than you realised.

data.text: Ride some flat surfaces, make it easier to get used to pedaling and being on the bike for longer periods of time. Hills can be daunting and a mood killer if you're not ready for them.
data.author: Rob Peters

data.text: It‚Äôs humbling. Many of us have been there. I still often get tired on mile 2-3 but then feel better as I go further. You‚Äôll be strong faster than you think. Keep after it.

data.text: yeah I was humbled very quickly lol. I was definitely put in my place.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Me too. The good thing is you can overcome. My first "ride" was the Black Canyon trail in AZ - 80 miles of rocky single track. One of the hardest things I ever did, came out stronger after that two days of hell :)

data.text: Well take it easy start with a mile a day and work up üôÇ you can get back in shape

data.text: I'm 65 and got back into biking about 6 years ago, following a total knee replacement I couldn't make the leg go all the way around when I started on stationary bike...YOU CAN DO THIS!!
data.author: Rick Adler

data.text: It‚Äôs just like‚Ä¶riding a bike üòú Just gotta do the thing and it‚Äôll get easier quickly!

data.text: Tomorrow you can do 11 minutes.
data.author: Timothy Faust

data.text: An old rule of thumb is to not increase time or speed by more than 10% a week. As others here have said, keep rising and you will get better.
data.author: Jim Weingart

data.text: When I got back into riding last year after a long absence, the 2.5 mile round trip to my mailbox nearly killed me. Today, 20 miles is nothing and 50+ is Easily possible. Hang in there, it will happen.
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: Once I was out riding and an old guy stopped to chat. He was riding his bike but dressed in blue jeans and a baseball cap...definitely not a cool biking look. He told me that 2 years ago he weighed 250 lbs, had high bp and type 2 diabetes. His doctor told him he would be dead within a year unless he made some changes. He went home, got out his son's old bike and managed to ride a half mile from his house then coast back. Now he weights 170, his bp and diabetes are cured and he has a 6 mile circuit he rides 10 times a day. If he can do it YOU can do it!
data.author: Steve Dintaman

data.text: I'm fortunate that I'm still pretty young and I'm not overweight. That story is inspiring. I can only imagine how difficult that journey was for him to start. I look forward to being in riding shape.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Yeah, I was pretty sure you had a head start on him! I started riding again when I retired at age 68. Now at age 70 I am riding over 5000 miles a year and doing the occasional bikepacking outing. I never felt like I put out any great, heroic training effort, just kept riding and riding until my legs, heart and butt were ready for long days of riding.
data.author: Steve Dintaman

data.text: wow that's bad ass. To be able to do that much at that age. That's amazing, I'm hoping to be in great shape like that in my last years as well.

data.text: What you experienced is, as they say, a good start. Do fifteen minutes today! And twenty tomorrow. If you keep that up, you‚Äôll be at double century distances in 90 days. Just keep at it.
data.author: Carlton Duty II

data.text: Your stamina will improve quickly. Don‚Äôt overdo it but be persistent/regular in your efforts. Remember: riding bikes is supposed to be fun! Set some modest goals (distance or time out riding), stop and enjoy your surroundings and bask in the joy of two wheels!
data.author: Wade Patterson

data.text: There's no overnight fix. When I restarted cycling, I did a nine mile circuit for ages before going on longer rides. Now I hardly ever ride those roads as I think they're too close to home! Keep at it though. Definitely worth it
data.author: Adrian Smith

data.text: I smoked for twenty years, not doing ANY exercise in that time. I quit and decided to do the AIDS/LifeCycle ride from San Francisco to Los Angeles. The first training rides were in January, and it was pretty pathetic. The first ride was from Chrissy Field in SF to Lake Merced, not that far away. I couldn‚Äôt make it up the tiniest hill without having to walk and stop for a breather. But I kept at it. We did the same ride a month later - no problem at all. I was amazed. It‚Äôs incredible how fast your body can get in shape if you just stick with it.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: awesome story. Yeah, I'll just keep at it. I look forward to getting back into it.

data.text: as I recall, a month after that, I did my first century (100 mile) ride.

data.author: Alan Houghton

data.text: A lot of advice here follows conventional sports wisdom but therefore overlooks a dirty little secret about bike touring (and more recently for me, bikepacking) that can be true. {The advice probably comes from people who do stretches before exercise. Bless 'em} You might not need to build up towards anything. Load the bike as close to ultralight as you can and just go. The first 2-3 days can be difficult and risky (so choose them well) but if you do days >60km you'll get fit on the bike rapidly. By day 3, you'll be surprised how far you've progressed and within a few more days you'll be at 100km/day. It's a strategy with a few risks, but this is one of the few pastimes where just throwing yourself in the deep end can work.
data.author: Brad Coombes

data.text: Brad, I‚Äôm guessing that Miltiades is at least 40 years old, if he has been off the bike for 10 years. Jumping in the deep end can be injurious for us old folks. Feeling sick after 10 minutes is a bad symptom, which might signal disease worse than simple deconditioning.
data.author: Rian Mintek

data.text: If your just starting back then develop a plan of each day doing a little more than the day before. 4 years ago I started back. The first two weeks were brutal. First day was like 4 blocks and ready to stop due to the pain in my thighs and ankles. Gradually the pain disappears day by day. Now I love to ride and usually and mostly pain free. It depends on how hard I push, if I am riding with faster riders or doing a lot of slow hills. Plan to enjoy it. Start out just the bike and some spare parts. Learn to fix things like flats, chains and adjustments like derailleur and brakes. Enjoy the journey and build your experience a step at a time.
data.author: Mark Wilson

data.text: yup that's my plan, I don't know anything about flats, tubeless, much maintenance in general. I want to learn though, it'll be a more enjoyable experience if I'm prepared for that, instead of having anxiety about being clueless.

Check out the bikepacking channel and search for others. The bikepacking community is one that is really helpful and supportive of each other.

I wish you luck learning and getting back into everything. I am over weight and about to be struggling getting back to where I was a year ago after my first long distance (300miles) trip.

data.text: Several years ago we moved to a house on a hill & I was determined to start cycling to & from work. The first day, I really struggled getting up the hill back to my house, but it gradually got easier. After commuting by bike for a few years, & adding on some cycling vacations, I changed jobs, so my work was now 25km away. I was pleasantly surprised when I found the first commute to & from the new location quite easy & enjoyable, & I didn‚Äôt even think of the hill climb to get back home as a challenge. It will get easier for you too. Just keep riding!

data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: when you sit on the saddle and put your heel on the pedal your leg should be straight with the knee locked. This will mean that when you pedal with the ball of your foot your leg will have a slight bend at the bottom of the pedal stroke. That's the best way to find the optimal seat height. Getting everything right will prevent you from tiring fast and cramping much less.
data.author: Fred Chagnon

data.text: thanks for that info. I'm gonna go down and test it out here shortly. I didn't do any of that.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: what about the seat position horizontally?
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text:
https://ilovebicycling.com/fore-aft-saddle-position/
Fore Aft Saddle Position - I Love Bicycling
ilovebicycling.com
data.author: Fred Chagnon

data.text: generally start in the middle of the seat rails, with seat horizontal. adjust forward or backward (not tilting) depending on reach to handlebars. Don't use the forward/backward adjustment as a main way to adjust leg reach (although you may need to go back to this if you change much). Total bike fitting can be an art, and might be worth investing paying for at a local bike shop. I generally do it myself and tinker a lot on rides until it feels right. All this said, my original comment was mainly about seat height which is easy to play with. Often if its even a bit too low, it robs your strength as if you were trying to walk around for a while in bent-leg crouch. The other stuff (seat angle/ forward-backward adjustment) tends to be more about arms/neck/shoulder pain. Other basic tip-- remember to use your gears. Expect to use them so that you are peddling relatively fast and without too much power. Think light jog, not squats.
data.author: Stephen Feeley

data.text: thanks a lot for all these tips. All the biking I did when I was younger was on a bmx bike. Basically always doing "squats" lol. I'll pay attention to the seat, and my body and see where I may need to make adjustments
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: The heel on pedal for saddle height is a myth that just won't die. It doesn't take into account thickness of heel of shoe, your foot size or how your ball of foot relates to heel when you pedal. It's very inaccurate for me. There is no simple quick answer. You also need to get your saddle fore/aft position setup correctly. You are best raising saddle with ball of foot over pedal axle until your knee is not quite straightened fully. From there adjust up or down by small increments and riding to see what works best for you. If my saddle is just 2mm lower than normal, I feel like I'm tired on bike. Saddle fore/aft position should result in front of knee cap being over pedal axle when cranks are horizontal. Again slightly fore of back of this may work better for yourself. I prefer to pedal with ball of foot much lower than heel. Not the same as pointing toes downwards. Try walking upstairs [same basic biomechanical action for downstroke] with a lower than usual or even level heel/ball and you will quickly see how efficiency varies.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: Start slow and add 5-10 minutes each day or
data.author: Andrew Mackey

data.text: Keep at it, do a little more every day. It takes time to adjust to getting back in to it. Also as your rides get longer and longer make sure to stay hydrated and keep eating on your rides.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: It gets easier very quickly so please hang in there. Most of us started this way. What's helped me is to understand the beauty of bikepacking is that things look nicer as you ride slower. Cheers.
data.author: Josh Fernandez

data.text: Hey! So I just started a year ago after a long break too and of my gosh the sore muscles the next day were killing me (I mean it. I could barely go to the toilet). My advice: 1. Don‚Äôt ride around aimlessly. Find a cool place a few km further than the previous day and go there - having a destination helps, and gives you sense of achievement after you reach it. 2. Consider an ebike - not the one that you don‚Äôt pedal at all, but the one that adds a few kmph to your speed IF you‚Äôre pedaling. It will help you go further and boost motivation. 3. If there are no cool places around, bribe yourself. Like, ‚Äúif I cycle 20km today I‚Äôll get my favorite snack‚Äù. It doesn‚Äôt work for everyone, but it has helped me üòå
data.author: Kay Anky JS

data.text: How is your cadence? Lots of people cycle wrong. They jump on the big ring and think they‚Äôre getting a great workout if it‚Äôs hard peddling. Your not. Keep a high cadence, and shift often.Ôøº
data.author: Tim Attwood

data.text: thanks for the tip. I'll do some research on this too
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Congrats with the new bike. Look at the bright side - it can only get better :)
data.author: Amir Shahar

data.text: I am not sure what you did in terms of hills, speed, etc. But i think you will find that if you keep at it, start on paved, flattish rail trails, and go at a slow, steady pace, it won't be hard to do 5, then 10, eventually 20 miles. Once you can do 20 miles, it's not that big a leap to get to 40 or more. So just pace yourself, go on easy flat paths, and your biking stamina will increase quickly.
data.author: Dave Elmstrom

data.text: We all have to start somewhere!
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: I wasn‚Äôt in the worst shape when I started. But I also wasn‚Äôt in the best shape. I still remember getting 5 miles from the house and doing 3 miles with a 0.5-1% incline and being so out of breath that I probably would‚Äôve vomited if I had enough lung volume in me to üòÖ Now I chug into a headwind at a much faster pace and not out of breath on that same stretch. It‚Äôs nice to look back at how far I‚Äôve come from that day! You‚Äôll get stronger and faster each day! Just be patient, take your time and most importantly have fun!!
data.author: Tami Nelson

data.text: What doesn‚Äôt kill you makes you stronger, keep pushing you‚Äôll be clocking 60 mile rides before you know it.
